In this example, this amount is the FX valuation for capitalized cost recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Position Currency

- 997,017.02

Positive value for positive amortization; Negative value for negative amortization.

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in PC (part of the initial discount 2,012,000.00 USD) which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Valuation Currency

-850,021.40

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Discount in PC

-1.014.982,98

Positive value for premium, negative value for discount, in case of liability position; Positive value for discount, negative value for premium, in case of asset position.

This is only needed when the amortization procedure of the position management procedure uses ‘gross method’ in SAP TRM; if amortization procedure uses ‘net method’, then there’s no need to enter value for these two fields of ‘Discount’ within TPM63B.

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Discount in VC

-863.397.80

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

-258,333.33

Usually, enter positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from issuance; enter negative value for accrual of expenses from issuance, or deferral of income from investment.

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system, and the assumption is that SAP TRM use reset procedure for TPM44 accrual after go-live.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

-219,531.66

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

Reset Date

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes: Not every available field of TPM63B are listed in the above table.

Initial Load of Position Values

After the data has been entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, and transfer it to the position management of TRM for this security position.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, discount account, accrual account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

The bond payable, unamortized discount, and accrual account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this security position, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

In this example, the “gross method” is used for the amortization procedure. Therefore, the bond payable account reflects the face value of the issued bonds (100,000,000.00 USD / 84,980,000.00 EUR, reflecting the latest exchange rate 0.8498). From an accounting standpoint, the carrying amount of the security position (short-term liability) is calculated as the face value minus the unamortized discount (1,014,982.98 USD / 863,397.80 EUR), resulting in 98,985,017.02 USD / 84,116,602.20 EUR.

You may wonder why accrual is reset on 01.01.2026—this is to ensure the accuracy of interest expenses for the month of January 2026 under the reset procedure of TPM44. For a detailed explanation of the rationale, please refer to the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which elaborates on the underlying reasons. While this blog uses an example of an investment OTC transaction, the core logic is consistent with the security position scenario, so we will not repeat the details here. This same blog also covers the handling of legacy data transfer for the difference procedure of TPM44, which requires assigning additional update types in configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, we will not elaborate further on this configuration step and process of difference procedure either.

Check the position flows in TPM13:

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

This blog has essentially come to a close. In the above example, we assumed that the legacy system and SAP TRM adopt the same calculation and posting logic for position components, enabling direct one-to-one mapping during legacy data migration. However, this is not always the case in practice—there are usually some discrepancies between the two systems to varying degrees. How to address these discrepancies? Below are several alternative approaches for reference:

  • Treat the legacy security businesses as if they had been processed in SAP TRM from their inceptions, simulate the position component values as of the cut-off date in SAP TRM and use these simulated values as the “benchmark”. Any discrepancies between these values and those from the legacy system are adjusted in the financial statements as of the cut-off date, classified as accounting estimate changes or accounting error corrections, etc. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Accept the discrepancies between the legacy system and SAP TRM, and directly proceed with subsequent processing in accordance with SAP TRM logic. However, the results of subsequent measurement and derecognition after system go-live (e.g., amortization, foreign exchange valuation, realized gain/loss) may be inconsistent with those generated by the legacy system. This approach requires specific confirmation from the auditors.
  • Modify the configuration in SAP TRM to align or approximate its processing logic with that of the legacy system. This approach is particularly applicable when the legacy security businesses were previously managed also in the TRM module of SAP ECC or S/4HANA On-Premise and now needs to be migrated to the TRM module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for continued management. In such cases, you can adjust the TRM configuration in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to make it consistent or closely aligned with the configuration in the former system.

Additional Notes

  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Legacy Data Transfer.
  • In the example above, the issuance cost 12,000.000 USD is managed in a standalone composition component ‘capitalized costs’, which requires additional configuration modifications, the details are omitted herein.
  • Which DT_* update types are invoked for TPM63 is specified in configuration activity 106944 “Assign Update Types for Legacy Data Transfer”. Sample configuration:
  • This blog only outlines certain means and posting patterns associated with legacy data transfer; such postings can vary based on specific business requirements and can be implemented with the various flexibilities offered by the SAP system.
  • App Reverse Transfer of Security Position Indicator (app ID: TPM62) is used to reverse the transfer done by TPM61.
  • App Reverse Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM64) is used to reverse results from TPM63.

entry.title: Using Common Activity Types in Professional Services and Service Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for Professional Services, there are 20 default T-activity types that are delivered out of the box by SAP. In some companies, it could be the case that these activity types are required to be used in both the lines of business professional service as well as service order management. In professional service, the association between activity types and the bill rates are automatically maintained using the billing profile configuration settings. Please refer to the following blog post by Tobias Schmidt for a deeper look into this topic.

In this blog post, I would like to demonstrate for the service management line-of-business, which configuration needs to be done to fulfill this requirement.

 

The scenario I would like to illustrate in this blog post is the business need, wherein common activity types are used between the lines of business professional services and service order management in S/4HANA Cloud. This is common in certain industries

  • Create/rename the activity types: In the app “Manage Activity Types”, rename the standard activity types T001 to T020 according to your business needs. The standard T- activity types can be renamed to correspond If needed, create further activity types beyond the 20 default activity types delivered out-of-the-box.

    •  

  • Create the cost rates: next, in the “Manage Cost Rates – Services” app, maintain the individual cost rates for the different combinations of company code/cost center/activity type (and optionally Service Cost Level)

    •  

  • Create the service product master data: finally for the determination of the correct cost rates for the products used in the service orders, you will need to create separate product master data (with material type SERV and item category group SRVP), as the T-materials delivered out of the box can only be used in customer projects or internal projects due to the respective item category determination.

    •  

  • *Assign the activity types to service products: after creating the service products, you will need to assign these to the corresponding activity types in the configuration activity “Assign Activity Type to Service Product” (SSCUI 102920). For the professional service projects, the assignment is done implicitly using the configuration activity “Maintain Billing Profile” (SSCUI 103637)

    •  

 

With this setup, you can successfully use common activity types and cost rates and correctly determine them for the transactions in the different lines-of-business Professional Services and Service Management.

entry.title: Customer Returns Scrapping Process with WM storage locations in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to detail the customer returns process (Scope Item ‘BKP’) when it comes to customers that are using warehouse managed (WM) storage locations. As the official scope item test script and official documentation covers the process using simple inventory managed storage locations, I would like to use this blog post to showcase which additional steps occur due to a WM storage location being used. As a specific example for this blog post, I’ll be using the follow up activity 0012 (Scrapping) in the customer returns process to show the steps necessary as a result of using WM storage locations.

 

The process starts with the creation of a returns order (I will be using the advanced returns order with order type ‘CBAR’) and subsequent returns delivery. During the creation of the returns order, choose the follow-up activity “Receive Into Plant” (0001).

Now comes the first step, where these is a slightly different process than described in the test script due to the usage of a WM managed storage location. The returns delivery created in the first step will be distributed to the WMS system and therefore cannot be processed using the standard app. You will here need to use the WM specific app “Change Inbound Deliveries – Deliveries”:

 

Next, go into the delivery, post the goods receipt, and create the warehouse tasks, in this order.

 

After creating the warehouse tasks, go into them and confirm the picking:

 

 

Now that the returns delivery is processed, the next step is to continue with the material inspection in the warehouse (App: Enter Inspection Results – From Warehouse). Here, select the returns delivery, maintain the inspection code, and select the follow-up activity 0012 Scrapping, before saving and confirming the inspection:

 

Upon this, a new outbound delivery will be created in the returns overview, which is the basis for the scrapping. Now, two further important steps come into play, which also need to be executed additionally due to WM storage locations in place.

In the app “Process Posting Change Item”, select the appropriate warehouse number and execute. For the outbound delivery item in question, select the item and create a WT in the background:

 

Next, double-click on the line, which will open up the created warehouse task in the screen half below. Select the Warehouse task and confirm the WT in the background:

 

As a final step after this, you will need to use another specific app for this process variant, which is the app “Post Goods Issue – Unplanned”. Here as well, enter the warehouse number, select the GI process “scrapping”, and select Run:

 

After this, select the line, and execute Post GI. This finally posts the goods issue for scrapping, and the returned material is removed from the inventory of the plant.

 

With this, the main part of the customer returns process is complete, and the user simply needs to parallelly proceed with the refund control steps (credit memo or replacement delivery). To summarize, when it comes to using WM managed storage locations in this process for the scrapping scenario, the additional apps need to be used on WM side are “Change Inbound Deliveries – Deliveries”, “Process Posting Change Item”, and “Post Goods Issue – Unplanned”.

entry.title: OData Service of Business Partner in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog provides a complete walkthrough on enabling the API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service for maintaining Business Partner data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, covering both Public Edition and Private Edition. The blog consolidates prerequisites, activation steps, and troubleshooting information into a single reference for technical consultants and integration teams.

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

The API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service enables CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on supported Business Partner entities, making it a core interface for inbound integration scenarios. This API is intended exclusively for CRUD operations, and it cannot be used for data replication purposes. For further information about API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, you can refer to the SAP Help Portal for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Private Edition.

Prerequisites

Before enabling the service, ensure that the system has at least one active Communication Arrangement for the communication scenario SAP_COM_0008.

Note: You do not need an existing SOAP replication service to enable or use this OData service.

If the scenario has not been configured yet, you can follow these steps –

  1. Create a communication user by following this link.
  2. Assign the communication user as your current S/4 system’s inbound communication user
    1. Open the Communication Systems app
    2. Click the Own SAP Cloud System button
    3. Choose Edit. Make a note of the System ID value, as it will be required for step 3.
    4. Under the Users for Inbound Communication tab, click the plus button to add a new user.
    5. Select the authentication method chosen for the user created in step 1.
    6. Enter the ID of the user created in step 1.
    7. Click the OK button.
    8. Save your changes. This will also be the user ID to authenticate the OData service.
  3. Create a new Communication Arrangement.
    1. Open the Communication Arrangements app.
    2. Click on the New button.
    3. Enter SAP_COM_0008 as the Scenario, and provide a concise, identifiable Arrangement Name.
    4. Under the Common Data tab, choose the current SAP Cloud system (noted down in step 2) as the Communication System.
    5. Under the Inbound Communication tab, choose the User Name as the user assigned to the current SAP System as per step 2.
    6. Deactivate all the services under the Outbound Services tab by unchecking the Service Status checkbox for each service.
    7. Save your changes.

Enabling the Service in Public Cloud

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the OData service for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER is activated automatically as soon as the communication arrangement for SAP_COM_0008 is created.

Locating the OData Endpoint

  1. Open the Communication Arrangements app.
  2. Select the relevant communication arrangement.
  3. Navigate to the Inbound Services tab.
  4. Locate the entry Business Partner (A2X) — the Service URL displayed here is your API endpoint.

Using the Endpoint

This URL can be consumed through:

  • Any third-party API testing tool
  • SAP API Sandbox
  • REST clients used in your existing landscape

Enabling the Service in Private Cloud

For S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, some additional manual checks are required to activate and validate the service.

1. Register or Verify the OData Service

Follow these steps to ensure that API_BUSINESS_PARTNER is available in the SAP Gateway:

  1. Open Transaction: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE (Service Catalog).

  2. In the External Service Name filter, search for: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER
    • If found → continue to Step 6
    • If not → proceed to next step


  3. Click Add Service.


  4. Search again using External Service Name: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER and System Alias: LOCAL. If System Alias LOCAL doesn’t exist in the list of SAP System Aliases, press the button Add System Alias and add the value LOCAL.


  5. Add the service via the standard provisioning steps.

  6. Check if the ICF Node associated with the service is active in the Service Catalog (green traffic light). If not active, select the node → ICF Node dropdown menu → Activate. The service should now be active.

We can proceed to test our activated OData service.

Tip: If the system shows the message “SAP System Message: User no longer logged on” when launching a /IWFND transaction, prefix it with /n.

Example: /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

2. Test the Service

The service can be validated using the SAP Gateway Client:

  • Via the SAP Gateway Client button within the Service Catalog, or
  • Transaction: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT

 

Troubleshooting

Issue: Service Active but Not Usable (Private Cloud)

Even after registering and activating the service, you may encounter access issues.

Solution:

In the Service Catalog entry for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, ensure that the SAP System Alias is set to: LOCAL

 

Conclusion

Once you have successfully completed the setup steps outlined above for your respective S/4HANA Cloud edition, the API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service will be ready for integration into your landscape. For a comprehensive list of all supported entities and CRUD operations, refer to the SAP Business Accelerator for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Private Edition.

entry.title: IFRS 18 Compliance for TRM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Key Impacts and Approaches
entry.content:
IFRS 18 at a glance

The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) issued IFRS 18 Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements in April 2024. IFRS 18 replaces IAS 1 Presentation of Financial Statements, requirements in IAS 1 that are unchanged have been transferred to IFRS 18 and other Standards. IFRS 18 is effective from 1 January 2027, and companies are permitted to apply IFRS 18 before that date.

IFRS 18 aims to improve how companies communicate in their financial statements, with a focus on information about financial performance in the statement of profit or loss. IFRS 18 will affect all companies in all industries. Although IFRS 18 will not affect how companies measure financial performance, it will affect how companies present and disclose financial performance.

The main changes introduced by IFRS 18 include, but are not limited to:

  • In the statement of profit or loss — report two new defined subtotals including operating profit, based on a new set of requirements for classifying income and expenses in categories. The newly introduced categories are Operating, Investing and Financing.
  • In the notes — disclose information about some performance measures defined by management, which IFRS 18 identify as ‘management-defined performance measures’ (MPMs).
  • In both the primary financial statements and the notes — group items applying enhanced requirements for aggregation and disaggregation of information.

 

Purpose of this blog

With one year to go before IFRS 18 becomes officially effective, we are publishing this blog to provide corporate treasurers, treasury accountants, configuration experts, and implementation partners — who use, configure or implement the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition — with early insights into TRM-related financial performance presentation requirements (primarily TRM profit or loss-related postings), necessary configurations changes and implementation advice, to prepare an IFRS 18-compliant statement of profit or loss.

 

Impacts on Treasury and Risk Management

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) supports the management and measurement of debt, investments, and financial risks through a wide range of financial instruments, including OTC money market transactions, foreign exchange deals, securities, derivatives, and trade finance instruments.

The following mapping matrix outlines, at a detailed level, the potential relationships between profit or loss related line-item elements (classified in IFRS 18 categories) and TRM product categories/product types (as covered in the current scope of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).

From the matrix, you may see that the income and expenses arising from TRM may fall into any of the three categories required by IFRS 18 — Operating, Investing, or Financing — depending on the economic nature of the financial instrument and the business purpose for which the entity holds or uses it.

When preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IAS 1, usually it is sufficient that the TRM-generated posting journals only reflect the “nature” of the income or expenses, for example, the G/L account “fair value gain or loss” might be sufficient for recognizing the gains or losses arising from the fair value changes on financial assets (or liabilities when applicable) which are evaluated at “fair value through profit or loss (FVTPL)” under IFRS 9. However, when preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IFRS 18, a single G/L account "fair value gains or losses" is insufficiently granular, as it fails to reflect which category — or, to use a more direct term, the "function" — for classifying such income or expenses: operating, investing, or financing.

 

Realization approaches

To achieve fine-grained detail within TRM-generated posting journals while also reflecting the categories (operating, investing, or financing), basically two approaches are available:

Approach 1: via granular G/L accounts

Set up profit or loss accounts with enhanced granularity, such that each account maps unequivocally to one of the IFRS 18 presentation categories or “functions” (representing operating, investing, or financing), in addition to their “nature”. Under this approach, certain profit or loss accounts will need to be “duplicated threefold” (once for each category).

An ensuing question is how the fine-grained profit or loss accounts are going to be determined when the postings are generated from TRM — this will be addressed in the next section “Implementation advice”.

A clear disadvantage of this approach is the potential need to create an unnecessarily large number of “redundant” accounts, particularly if additional dimensions (e.g., relationship with the counterparty/issuer) need to be incorporated into the account structure as well.

Approach 2: via functional areas

Limit profit or loss accounts to reflecting only their “nature”, eliminating the need to create new G/L accounts (which is the major advantage of Approach 2). Instead, leverage functional areas to differentiate between the three presentation categories during the generation of posting journals from TRM, and the functional area should be from TRM OTC transactions or security positions.

An ensuing question is how the functional area is determined for TRM OTC transactions or security positions — this will be addressed in the next section “Implementation advice”.

 

Implementation advice

Self-configuration

This section outlines key configuration considerations for achieving successful implementation of Approach 1 or Approach 2 via self-configuration.

Approach 1: via granular G/L accounts

To manually implement Approach 1, first, please create additional fine-grained profit or loss accounts in General Ledger Accounting.

A critical subsequent consideration is how to determine the appropriate G/L account from the TRM module. As a key dimension for G/L account determination in TRM, Account Assignment References (AARs) shall be configured such that IFRS 18 categories (operating, investing, financing) are encoded in their IDs and names. This means AARs will need to be triplicated relative to those required for IAS 1-compliant profit or loss presentation requirements. AARs are created through configuration activity 102099 Define Account Assignment References.

The next critical configuration step is to derive AARs for OTC transactions and security positions. To accomplish this, please configure substitution rules for AAR derivation based on pre-conditions including (but not limited to) product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, and hedging classification, etc. For guidance on using the relevant substitution tools, refer to the help documentations:

  • Account Assignment References - OTC Transactions (Substitution Rules)
  • Account Assignment References - Securities (Substitution Rules)

The following table outlines potential pre-conditions for deriving AARs across different TRM product categories or product types:

As the last step, please assign the new G/L accounts to account symbols and new AARs via configuration activity 103014 Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management.

Approach 2: via functional areas

Approach 2 eliminates the need for additional G/L accounts. However, IFRS 18 presentation category granularity must still be embedded in new AARs, as the derivation of functional areas is dependent on the AARs. Additionally, substitution rules for new AARs derivation and the configuration for assignment of existing G/L accounts to account symbols and new AARs remain necessary.

Beyond the configurations outlined in Approach 1, Approach 2 requires the following additional configurations:

  • Create new functional areas to represent the three IFRS 18 categories (Operating, Investing, Financing) via configuration activity 102363 Define Functional Area.
  • In configuration activity 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References, assign the new functional areas to company codes and new AARs accordingly.

Once these configurations are completed, the functional area will be populated in the Position Indicator of newly created OTC transactions and security positions, following this determination sequence:

  1. Substitution rule derives the relevant AAR based on pre-conditions (e.g., product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, hedging classification).
  2. The configuration in activity 105341 determines the functional area from the company code and the already derived AAR. The functional area is then stored in the Position Indicator.

Subsequently, the functional area in the Position Indicator is propagated to the corresponding posting journals generated from TRM transactions and security positions. Moreover, the functional area supplied by the TRM position indicator (as the calling application) takes precedence over that derived from G/L account master data or account assignment (e.g., cost center, WBS element), if applicable. For further details, please refer to SAP help document: Deriving Functional Areas.

SAP best practice content

SAP plans to deliver additional best practice content for TRM through the introduction of new scope item(s) as part of the 2608 release.

The new scope item(s) is planned to be delivered exclusively for Central Business Configuration (CBC) and to include additional reference configuration content aligned with Approach 2 — such as new functional areas, new Account Assignment References (AARs), and new account determination configuration entries (assignment of existing G/L accounts to the new AARs). Therefore, the activation of the new scope item(s) will automatically deploy the relevant configuration — though some manual fine-tuning is expected to be unavoidable.

We expect this additional content to streamline the IFRS 18-compliant TRM implementation journey to some extent for a specific group of TRM customers.

Any news regarding the delivery of best practice content will be posted on this blog — please stay tuned. Please also note that this best practice content delivery plan is subject to change.

Choosing between self-configuration and SAP best practice content

This section outlines some criteria to help determine whether to implement via self-configuration or leverage SAP best practice content for supporting the implementation journey.

Self-configuration is required if any of the following applies:

  1. The configuration activities in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system are accessed via the app Manage Your Solution rather than Central Business Configuration (CBC); or
  2. TRM is already in productive use, with substantial amounts of customized configurations (e.g., customized AARs, G/L accounts, account determinations) — the core implication is that IFRS 18-related configurations will most likely also require customization, so the reference configuration content within new scope item(s) will not be very helpful; or
  3. It is required to start the TRM implementation for IFRS 18 compliance before the new scope item(s) are officially released in August 2026 (subject to change) — regardless of the driving factor, such as being an early adopter of IFRS 18 in early 2026.

If the configuration activities in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system are managed via CBC, you can leverage SAP Best Practice Content for implementation if any of the following applies:

  1. TRM is already in productive use, and the existing processes are running on the basis of reference content (e.g., configurations for AARs, G/L accounts, and account determinations are consistent with or closely aligned to reference content) — the core implication is that the new IFRS 18-related configurations provided by the new scope item(s), coupled with limited fine-tunings, will most likely meet IFRS 18 compliance requirements for TRM as well; or
  2. The overall TRM implementation (including non-IFRS 18-related configurations) has not yet commenced by the time the new scope item(s) are officially released in August 2026 (subject to change); or
  3. The overall TRM implementation (including non-IFRS 18-related configurations) is in progress by August 2026 (when the new scope item(s) are officially released, subject to change), but TRM has not yet gone live — and it is confirmed at that point that TRM processes will rely heavily on reference content.

Considerations for the implementation project timeline

IFRS 18 will be effective from 1 January 2027, meaning related financial statements for annual reporting periods beginning on or after this date must be prepared in accordance with this new standard.

Accordingly, the following TRM-related deliverables must be completed prior to the start of the 2027 fiscal year (for production tenants where TRM will have been in productive use by the end of 2026) or prior to the TRM go-live date (for production tenants where TRM will be in productive use in 2027 or later):

  1. Align TRM business processes and posting requirements with IFRS 18 mandates. More specifically, determine whether to adopt Approach 1, Approach 2, or any other viable methodologies not described in this blog.
  2. Update system configurations manually (self-configuration implementation approach), or activate IFRS 18-related SAP best practice content scope item(s) and fine-tune the system configurations accordingly.
  3. Conduct end-to-end testing of TRM business processes and posting results in the test tenant.
  4. Transport validated configurations to the production tenant, and run account assignment reference transfer if necessary (please refer to the section “Outstanding transactions and security positions” for details).

The implementation for TRM may form part of a larger initiative (e.g., a company-wide IFRS 18 compliance program or an ERP implementation project). Additionally, considerations for how to incorporate and aggregate TRM-generated profit or loss posting journals into individual (and consolidated, if applicable) statement of profit or loss are also critical but not elaborated upon in this blog.

 

Outstanding transactions and security positions

For production tenants where TRM will have been in productive use by the end of 2026 (or by the planned transition date to IFRS 18-aligned processes following configuration updates), all outstanding OTC transactions and security positions must be “converted” to ensure that subsequent postings generated from these transactions or positions are IFRS 18-compliant.

To facilitate this “conversion”, the functionality Transfer Account Assignment Reference (App ID: TPM28) is recommended.

Executing TPM28 performs the following core actions:

  • Transfers existing (legacy) Account Assignment References (AARs) to new, IFRS 18-compliant AARs. New AARs will appear in the Position Indicator of OTC transactions and security positions afterwards.
  • Posts position transfers at book value between the old and new AARs — specifically, it clears the position using the position account derived from the legacy AAR and re-recognizes the same position using the position account determined by the new IFRS 18-compliant AAR.

However, this “conversion” typically does not invoke changes to position accounts. As such, the position transfer postings generated by TPM28 are unnecessary. To suppress these postings, you may mark relevant update types as non-posting relevant.

If Approach 2 (via functional areas) is adopted, execution of TPM28 will bring another update within the position indicator — the functional area (determined via configuration activity 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References) will be populated in the position indicator, associated to the new AAR.

TPM28 includes a checkbox: “Transfer of P&L Postings”. Enabling this indicator triggers the transfer of all related profit or loss postings for the current fiscal year up to the TPM28’s key date — legacy profit or loss postings derived from the old AAR are cleared, and profit or loss postings are re-recognized based on the new AAR. For Approach 2, these re-recognition postings will also include the relevant functional area.

Using TPM28 with the “Transfer of P&L Postings” indicator may fulfill IFRS 18’s requirement for the restatement of profit or loss for comparative period (typically the 2026 fiscal year). To achieve this, TPM28 is supposed to executed at the end of the fiscal year 2026. One important point to note is that the restatement requirement mandated by IFRS 18 applies at the statement level; In contrast, TPM28 — when the “Transfer of P&L Postings” indicator is enabled — facilitates “re-posting” actually. The outcome of this “re-posting” may ultimately enables the achievement of the statement-level restatement required by IFRS 18.

For further details, please refer to the SAP Help document: Transfer Account Assignment Reference.

 

Embed ‘categorization' throughout the E2E hedging process

Appropriate categorization of profit or loss is a fundamental requirement for applying IFRS 18 within TRM. However, some TRM users may have additional requirements beyond this — for instance, embedding the concept of ‘categorization’ across the entire end-to-end hedging process for foreign exchange (FX) risk.

Hedge management of net open exposures (FX risk)

Within the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures (FX Risk) functionality, the Hedge Management Cockpit app serves as the central tool, providing a consolidated overview of FX exposures and the corresponding FX derivatives used to mitigate FX risk within a defined hedging area.

The exposures managed by the Hedge Management Cockpit usually arise from variability in cash flows that is attributable to FX risks associated with highly probable forecast transactions, unrecognized firm commitments, or recognized assets or liabilities.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this E2E net open exposure hedging process, the setup of Hedging Areas (the process starting point) must include differentiation criteria — such as portfolio — to represent IFRS 18 categories for both exposures and hedges.

Accordingly, when the FX exposures are created, the IFRS 18 category-representative portfolio must be explicitly specified in the exposures to differentiate exposure categories. This portfolio will then propagate throughout the entire process, including:

  • Snapshots of exposures
  • Hedge requests
  • Trade requests (if Trading Platform Integration is enabled)
  • Ultimately, the FX derivatives themselves (e.g., FX forwards, FX options)

The substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition, enabling the derivation of category-representative Account Assignment References (AARs) for the FX derivatives. Subsequently, all posting journals generated from these FX derivatives will be IFRS 18-compliant — regardless of whether aforementioned Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

Hedge management of balance sheet FX risk

The Hedge Management of Balance Sheet FX Risk functionality is designed to capture the FX exposures arising from the changes in fair value of recognized assets or liabilities that are attributable to FX risk, and the FX exposures will be subsequently mitigated through corresponding FX derivatives.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this end-to-end balance sheet FX risk hedging process, balance sheet FX exposures must include category-related information at the process outset. To achieve this, it is recommended to create distinct category-representative Key Figure Groups, which can be differentiated based on criteria such as G/L accounts.

Subsequent steps include:

  • Generating snapshots based on these distinct Key Figure Groups — these snapshots will also be segregated by the IFRS 18 categories.
  • Creating hedge requests separately from each snapshot. During this step, explicitly assign the corresponding category-representative portfolio to each snapshot, ensuring hedge requests are segregated by the IFRS 18 categories via the portfolio dimension.
  • If Trading Platform Integration is enabled, trade requests will inherit the portfolio from the corresponding hedge requests.
  • Ultimately, the FX derivatives (e.g., FX forwards, FX options) will be linked to the relevant category-representative portfolios.

Similar to the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures process, the substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition to derive category-specific AARs for the FX derivatives. Posting journals generated from these FX derivatives will then be IFRS 18-compliant — regardless of whether Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

Classify all gains and losses on FX derivative in the operating category

Under IFRS 18, the default requirement is that all gains and losses on a derivative used to manage identified risks shall be classified in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks being managed. This basic principle is also reflected in all previously described examples relevant to FX derivatives.

However, if applying this basic principle would lead to the grossing up of gains and losses, all gains and losses on the derivative shall instead be classified in the operating category. Additionally, for a derivative that is not designated as a hedging instrument under IFRS 9 hedge accounting but is used to manage identified risks, if classifying its gains and losses into specific categories would involve undue cost or effort, all such gains and losses on the derivative shall likewise be classified in the operating category.

IFRS 18 states that grossing up of gains and losses might arise from situations in which:

  1. an entity uses financial instruments to manage the risks of a group of items with offsetting risk positions; and
  2. the risks managed affect line items in more than one category of the statement of profit or loss.

IFRS 18 provides an example in which grossing up of gains or losses on a FX derivative might arise: an entity may use a derivative to manage both the net foreign currency risk on revenue (classified in the operating category) and interest expenses (classified in the financing category). In such cases, the foreign exchange differences on the revenue are offset by the foreign exchange differences on the interest expenses and the gains or losses on the derivative. However, the entity classifies the foreign exchange differences on the revenue in a different category from the foreign exchange differences on the interest expenses. To present the gain or loss on the derivative in each category, an entity would need to present in each category a larger gain or loss than occurred on the derivative. Applying the requirements in paragraphs B70–B73 of IFRS 18, an entity shall not gross up the gains or losses in this manner and instead shall classify any gain or loss on the derivative in the operating category.

These provisions under IFRS 18 establish a “practical exception” — meaning that the approach described in the sections Hedge management of net open exposures (FX risk) and Hedge management of balance sheet FX risk (where categories are segmented at the exposure level first and passed through the E2E process) may not be required in certain scenarios. Specifically, when conditions for grossing up of gains and losses or undue cost or effort are met, it is permissible to classify all gains and losses from FX derivatives in the operating category instead of segmenting them across multiple categories. For confirmation on the applicability of this treatment in practice, please consult your auditors in detail.

entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Part 1
entry.content:
Co-Author : @Chandrashekhar_Tipre 

Introduction

The SAP Community blog by @gunther_sanchez  introduces how SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) can be used together with SAP Cloud ERP.  It explains the supported deployment scenario where a decentralized SAP EWM system in SAP Cloud ERP Private or on-premises can integrate with the SAP Cloud ERP to deliver advanced warehouse capabilities.

The integration scenario supports connecting a single SAP Cloud ERP Tenant to one SAP EWM for SAP Cloud ERP Private instance. In addition, an extra SAP Cloud ERP Private system can also be integrated with the same SAP EWM , enabling a shared warehouse management setup across multiple ERP landscapes.

Benefits

The hybrid integration of decentralized SAP EWM with SAP Cloud ERP allows organizations to adopt a clean-core, cloud-first ERP while still leveraging the rich, mature, and highly configurable warehouse functionalities of full-scale SAP EWM. This approach supports complex warehouse operations, more flexible process tailoring, advanced logistics features, and higher automation potential.

Business Process

Let’s take a deep dive into the two of the supported Business Processes.

  • SAP EWM Integration - Inbound Processing from Supplier 

Inbound processing from a supplier begins when a purchase order in SAP Cloud ERP triggers the creation of an inbound delivery. This delivery is sent to decentralized SAP EWM, where an inbound delivery notification is created to drive warehouse execution. SAP EWM manages unloading, checking, goods receipt, and put away task generation based on warehouse rules. Once put away is completed confirmations flow back to SAP Cloud ERP to post the goods receipt and update stock and financials.

 

  • SAP EWM Integration - Outbound Processing to Customer 

Outbound processing starts when a sales order in SAP Cloud ERP triggers the creation of an outbound delivery. This delivery is sent to decentralized SAP EWM, where an outbound delivery order is created to drive warehouse execution. SAP EWM manages picking, packing, staging, and loading based on configured warehouse processes. After loading, Goods Issue is posted in EWM, and the confirmation is sent back to SAP Cloud ERP to posts the Goods Issue and updates stock and financials accordingly.

       

Conclusion

Overall, integrating decentralized EWM with SAP Cloud ERP offers a balanced approach—combining advanced warehouse capabilities with the flexibility and simplicity of a cloud-native ERP.

entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Part 2
entry.content:
Co-Author : @Chandrashekhar_Tipre 

Introduction

In this blog we will continue with the set up for The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP.  Please refer for Process to The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Part 1 blog .

Set-up in SAP Cloud ERP

Create Communication arrangement SAP_COM_0A58.

The communication system should have below details to connect with cloud connector.

The username and password for Outbound Communication user must be same as of technical user in SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

Inbound username and password should be same as RFC destination created in SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

Maintain The cloud connector setup for type RFC

Set up in SAP Extended Warehouse Management 

The below system is explained in terms of Integration points between SAP EWM and SAP Cloud ERP

1. In Extended Warehouse Management, Define Business system

The business system is the logical system of cloud

2. Assign Warehouse Numbers from Logical System

3. IDoc Interface / Application Link Enabling (ALE) : Define Logical System

4. Assign Business Partners to Plant

5. Control for RFC Queue

6. Create RFC Destination

The user Id and password is what is maintained in communication arrangement in SAP Cloud ERP.

7. Assign Default RFC Destinations to Logical Systems

8. Map Storage Locations from ERP System to EWM

9. Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

10. Control Message Processing Dependent on Recipient

11. Assign Logical System and Queue Type

Conclusion

This blog post should help you to understand in detail on how to integrate The SAP Extended Warehouse Management  with SAP Cloud ERP

Thanks for reading this blog post, hopefully the blog post was informative.
